name: Federación Española de Mujeres Directivas, Ejecutivas, Profesionales y Empresarias
goal:
The Spanish Federation of Women Directors, Executives, Professionals and Businesswomen (FEDEPE) groups under its acronym 21 professional women's associations throughout the national territory that represent more than 24,000 members from different sectors.

Since its creation, FEDEPE has been the voice of managers, entrepreneurs, executives, unemployed or women workers who have hit the glass ceiling. Proposing new policies to prevent that society wastes female talent and progress towards an equitable model are permanent goals.

FEDEPE's mission is to create a "we" in femenine and a notion of group, to act reflexively in the different social and profesional environments, with the objetive of promoting the development of its members and empowering women.

The working tools are building of social awareness, creating collaboration and cooperation networks of women, lifelong learning, empowerment, and being active agents of change towards a business model of leadership closer to women's values, participating in academic, institutional and business forums, and in different media.

Objectives
- To create a professional and business environment that is adequate and dignified for women.
- Ensure that large companies internalize that productivity and profits are increased by applying equality and diversity criteria at all levels of the organization structure until natural equity is achieved in high management.
- Serve as a platform for the development of new social gender relations.
- Cooperate with initiatives that improve women's quality of life.
- Raise awareness, promote and consolidate women's access to management positions, and support young pre-executives.
- Identify barriers that still exclude women from executive positions and develop strategies to overcome them.
- To exchange knowledge and experiences of scientific and practical approximation to the development of management executed by women.
- Collaborate with public and private institutions and organizations whose objectives include promoting professional development and the presence of women in positions of responsibility.
- To build training and meeting platforms for its members.
- To create an environment of mutual support and a network to promote professional and business initiatives.

FEDEPE has been declared an Entity of Public Utility, a distinction granted by the Spanish State, and endorses the effectiveness, transparency and good practices of the Federation.

FEDEPE is a member of the Women's Participation Council, the official dialogue body between women's organizations and public administrations, with the aim of promoting public policies in favour of gender equality, and of the Equality Observatory of Spanish Radio Television. FEDEPE is also a consultative member of the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) which participates systematically with, contributing its vision on the gender issues that concern it.

It is also a member of Spanish Confederation of Directors and Executives (CEDE), the Independent Foundation, the National Commission for the Rationalisation of Spanish Timetables (ARHOE), the Genova Financial Club, the Federation of Advertising and Communication Companies (LA FEDE), the Association for the Diffusion and Promotion of Spain's World Heritage (ADIRPOPE) and the Civil Society Now Association.

FEDEPE works with different organizations and institutions in order to promote and consolidate the objectives of the federation. Some of its main allies are: the Cervantes Institute, the ONCE Foundation, UN Women, the Conference of Rectors of Spanish Universities (CRUE), the National Library of Spain and the Vicente Ferrer Foundation.

We know that, despite the victories achieved, there are still many victories to conquer, such as equal pay, co-responsibility or conciliation. This is the challenge that forms the structure of the day-to-day and the DNA of our Federation.
interests: Business and Industry, Communication, Consumers, Culture, Culture and media, Digital economy and society, Economy, finance and the euro, Education and training, Employment and Social Affairs, External Relations, Institutional affairs, International co-operation and development, Justice and Fundamental Rights, Public Health, Research and innovation, Sport, Taxation, Trade, Youth
euInitiatives:
All those legislative or policy initiatives related to gender equality, against labour discrimination on grounds of sex, those relating to changes in working hours or work-life balance, employment and entrepreneurship.

As well as those concerned with:
- Article 157 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU): Principle that men and women should receive equal pay for equal work. Authorises positive action to empower women.

- Article 153 TFEU: Allows the EU to act in the wider area of equal opportunities and equal treatment in matters of employment and occupation.

- Article 19 TFEU enables the adoption of legislation to combat all forms of discrimination, including on the basis of sex.

- Articles 2 and 3(3) of the Treaty on European Union (TEU): It bases equality as values and promotes equality between men and women.

- Article 21 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights

- Article 8 TFEU gives the Union the task of eliminating inequalities and promoting equality between men and women through all its activities (this concept is also known as ‘gender mainstreaming’).

- Regulation (EU) No 1381/2013 establishing a Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme for the period 2014 to 2020

- Council Directive 2004/113/EC of 13 December 2004 implementing the principle of equal treatment between men and women in the access to and supply of goods and services

- Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation

- Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation

- Directive 2010/41/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 7 July 2010 on the application of the principle of equal treatment between men and women engaged in an activity in a self-employed capacity and repealing Council Directive 86/613/EEC.

- Directive (EU) 2019/1158 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2019 on work-life balance for parents and carers

- European Parliament’s Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM)

- The European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE)

- The EIGE as chair of the Justice and Home Affairs (JHA) agencies’ network

- The Women’s Charter and the Strategic engagement for gender equality 2016-2019

- Gender Action Plan 2016-2020

- Sustainable Development Goals, SDG, especially the number 5.
